summary: The U.S. District Court for the Western District of Kansas today entered a final judgment against Rance D. James, Jr., a convicted felon who was sentenced to prison for second- and third-degree murder in May 2015.  The SEC's complaint, filed in federal court in Kansas City, alleges that James entered the basement of the Parrot-fa-Nalia dress shop on May 8, 2015, to participate in a party hosted by friends and family members. According to the complaint, James and one of his friends, Artadius "Ta Ta" Johnson, entered the room and confronted the defendant, telling him that he had just gotten out of prison and was "mugging" James throughout the night. The complaint alleges that the defendant replied, "I'm not worried about the time. I'm just afraid of the time."  The complaint further alleges that Johnson and McClennon followed him down the stairs and into the basement, where they were confronted by a group of men who claimed to be members of a "gang" who had shot James.  James allegedly told the men that he "wanted them to meet each other" but "it went bad right away because he was leaving to get a gun."  He also allegedly told one of the men to "squash" James' gun and "don't trip on that."  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York today announced criminal charges against James arising from the same conduct alleged in the SEC's Complaint.  In its complaint, the SEC alleges that Judge Ternes violated the antifraud provisions of Section 17(a) of the Securities Act of 1933 and Section 10(b) of Securities Exchange Act of 1934 and Rule 10b-5 thereunder.  Without admitting or denying the allegations of the SEC, James consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins him from violating the charged provisions of the federal securities laws, orders him to pay disgorgement of ill-gotten gains plus prejudgment interest, and imposes a five-year officer-and-director bar.  On August 19, 2019, the Honorable Judge John J. G. Sansone entered final judgments against James, ordering him to disgorge $1,078.71, pay a $100,000 civil penalty, and appoint a receiver to the receiver of the receiver's receiver.  Judge Sansone also ordered James to pay a civil penalty of $150,000, and ordered him to comply with the court's order.   The settlement is subject to court approval.
